comments.body:
Probably deserves a comment here that this is linked/copied from the one in controller-manager.

Or the controller-manager one should have a comment depending on which one we consider the source of truth.
Updating now.
Note: ` pkg/features/kube_features.go ` is always the source of truth for feature gates.

This is a breaking change. We should provide the deprecation warning for at least one release before we disable the feature gate. The deprecation policy has gotten even more complex since I last read it 😁 , but I think this is the part we want (where setting to `false` is the last thing we do, but we can set `featuregate.Deprecated` now):

> In some cases, removing pre-GA features requires considerable time. Feature gates can remain operational until their associated feature is fully removed, at which point the feature gate itself can be deprecated.

> Versioning for feature gates is different from the previously discussed components, therefore the rules for deprecation are as follows:

> Rule #8: Feature gates must be deprecated when the corresponding feature they control transitions a lifecycle stage as follows. Feature gates must function for no less than:

> Beta feature to EOL: 3 months or 1 release (whichever is longer)

> Rule #9: Deprecated feature gates must respond with a warning when used. When a feature gate is deprecated it must be documented in both in the release notes and the corresponding CLI help. Both warnings and documentation must indicate whether a feature gate is non-operational.

We should also mark the `Node.Spec.ConfigSource` field deprecated: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/staging/src/k8s.io/api/core/v1/types.go#L4610

FWIW, we might want to consider a 2 or 3 release timeline since that field is in core/v1 (it's technically beta, and the doc comment in core/v1 still mentions a feature gate is required, but might still be best to play it safe). @liggitt WDYT?

I read these rules as the feature gate should remain operational, but it says nothing about the defaults. So I kept it operational and for increased visibility into the change - disabled it. I understand that on the cluster upgrade, if wasn't re-enabled explicitly, it will stop working. But this is a beta feature and my assumption was that "Features can be removed at any point in the life cycle prior to GA". I'm happy to revert the change of default, I see arguments both ways.

I will add deprecation message to the fields, good catch. I was also thinking if `kubectl` should warn when these fields are used, but didn't find any precedence doing so. WDYT?

> We should provide the deprecation warning for at least one release before we disable the feature gate.

Someone who still needs to use it for the duration of the deprecation period will turn it on explicitly in 1.22, right? Someone who doesn't will not start accidentally using it in 1.22 without realizing it is beta. I would tend to change the default to false early to increase visibility.

> I would tend to change the default to false early to increase visibility.

I suppose that's fair, since it's most of our warning mechanisms (logs, help text, emails to kubernetes-dev) go ignored anyway...

comments.body: Can we document ESXi, vCenter and HW versions required for this to work? If we can't document this inline here - what is the canonical place where users who are looking to use this should find it?

I can add

```
-       // beta: v1.19
+       // beta: v1.19 (vSphere Version: 7.0u1, HW Version: VM version 15)
```

We will be also publishing documentation for migration. Issue - https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/vsphere-csi-driver/issues/236
We can provide detail in the doc as well.
Yes please, since this feature has explicit dependency - I would add it in as many places as possible.  Can you also clarify if both vcenter and esxi needs to be on 7.0u1 or just vcenter is fine?

Clarified both vCenter and ESXi needs to at 7.0u1

```
// beta: v1.19 (vSphere vCenter/ESXi Version: 7.0u1, HW Version: VM version 15)
```
Add a space between the features
I don't have strong feelings here. But the same comment applies: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/91930#discussion_r437685346

It's a bit different right? The feature here is "disabling the Accelerators metrics" not "Enabling the accelerator metrics". If it were the latter, then the feature would need to start with the enabled state, which doesn't seem right.

What do you think?

IMO the feature is `accelerator usage metrics` and it can be enabled or disabled. :) The above gives a strange "double negative" aka `DisableAcceleratorUsageMetrics == false` is negating a negative and can be prone to misunderstanding. 🤔 I get that the feature is the ability to turn them off I guess?

I can see it both ways, I personally would drop the `Disable` but that is just me.

At this stage the prefix Disable make more sense. My point is that in future metrics would be disabled by default and the feature will be to "Enable" them. Dropping prefix all together as @Klaven suggested is another option, like `CollectAcceleratorUsageMetrics` with values `true` or `false`.

By no means it's a blocking comment btw. Naming is hard.

The way that I look at it is that it's a a feature flag that is by default disabled, I don't think there's a way around that. 

The flag "AcceleratorUsageMetrics" and "EnableAcceleratorUsageMetrics" are pretty much the same flag and have the same problem where they would need to be enabled at first. I don't really see how we would work around the fact that feature flags are by nature disabled at first.

As you are mentioning above it would make sense if we could set the feature flag to true at first and then switch it to false but then we are going to confuse users because it's not really how other feature flags behave (or feature flags for that matter).

I'm a bit confused. I noticed that we set `LockToDefault` to `true` in `CSINodeInfo` as well, but if I understand the docs [1] correctly, these features are CLI arguments and they should work for at least one version:

```
Rule #5b: CLI elements of admin-facing components (e.g. kubelet) must function after their announced deprecation for no less than:

    GA: 6 months or 1 release (whichever is longer)
```

Shouldn't these features be deprecated (keep working with a warning) in this version and only locked in 1.18?

CC @msau42 @liggitt 

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-policy/#deprecating-a-flag-or-cli

see feature-gate-specific lifecycle in [section 7](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-policy/#deprecating-a-feature-or-behavior):

> An exception to the above rule is feature gates. Feature gates are key=value pairs that allow for users to enable/disable experimental features.
> 
> Feature gates are intended to cover the development life cycle of a feature - they are not intended to be long-term APIs. As such, they are expected to be deprecated and removed after a feature becomes GA or is dropped.
> 
> As a feature moves through the stages, the associated feature gate evolves. The feature life cycle matched to its corresponding feature gate is:
> ...
> GA: the feature gate is deprecated (see “Deprecation”) and becomes non-operational.

I can go ahead and add the feature flags CSIMigration[Plugin]Complete for all the plugins and assign the existing owners of CSIMigration[Plugin] as the maintainers of the feature flags. /cc @adisky and @andyzhangx for Openstack Cinder and AzureFile/AzureDisk respectively.
from GA feature, we just remove the feature gates :)
and for this feature, it's also to remove some predicates about node condition.
Please take another look, thanks!
No - we don't remove feature gates for GA (at least not immediately - otherwise if someone is setting up feature gate, we will break them).

we *do* lock to true when promoting to GA (`LockToDefault: true` in the feature gate setup), and remove code that checks the gate, but leave the gate itself there to give people one release to modify their CLI invocations
Addressed

@liggitt , @wojtek-t , when should remove the function code feature? Only keep feature gate for one release :)

And good to know we did not remove it immediately :)
one release. announce graduation to GA and feature gate deprecation in 1.17, then remove in 1.18

comments.body: I expected this to be set for struct initialized by the generic apiserver options, not here.
I think one negative of doing it that way is that the list of features/defaults would be split between multiple locations
It's already set in two places @jennybuckley, and I think what @deads2k is saying is that it should only be set in one place (the one in staging/src/k8s.io/apiserver/pkg/features/kube_features.go).
Oh, I see that makes sense. Don't we need these in both then?
I don't see why we'd need to add DryRun here, that's just increasing the leak.

We have it at two places intentionally. But there is code to detect when it diverges.

The reason to have all of them here is to have an overview over all existing feature flags.

I would not worry about this for the moment. We are going to refactor this structure to avoid leakage of the gates into other, unintended components. But we don't have to solve this here.

comments.body: It's worth thinking about how this will look once this feature reaches GA. I would still expect to be able to provide a kubelet with a serving cert/key and have it just use it without trying to self-rotate. At that point, would we want a GA feature gate that someone could disable? I'm a little unclear about the longevity of feature gates once they reach GA.
I don't think feature gates should be a long-term option. If we want something to toggle this after it goes to GA, it should be a separate flag.
I sort of agree. I'd expect people to opt into rotation/renewal even once this is GA, since it places requirements on deployments to set up signers backing the CSR API

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/46603

Does it seem reasonable to have one flag covering all the certificate rotation in the kubelet?
unless i am mistaken, you are only supporting this annotation if a pod is not BestEffort qos
i would also clarify here that its restricted to the kube-system namespace.
Ack. I will add the additional comments.
Done
